messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for March 18, 2020 - March 24, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-03-25T21:25:53Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-03-18T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-03-24T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20200325-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic period of 2020-03-19T00:00Z-03:00Z.  This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around 2020-03-17.  Solar wind speed reached values of >500 km/s on 2020-03-19.   

The >2 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^3 pfu starting at 2020-03-23T15:45Z. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES were elevated due to a possible combination of the coronal hole high speed stream described above and several small coronal holes high speed stream arrivals on 2020-03-21 and 2020-03-23, respectively. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the significantly elevated electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-03-25T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-03-31T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  There are no significant active regions present on the solar surface as seen on the available imagery. 
 Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the possible arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2020-03-28.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-03-11T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-03-17T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  The active region 12758 present on the Earth's facing side as seen from the SDO imagery has low magnetic complexity.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to a possible arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2020-03-14.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for February 26, 2020 - March 03, 2020
##
## Message Issue Date: 2020-03-05T02:21:54Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2020-02-26T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2020-03-03T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20200305-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2020-02-29T21:00Z-24:00Z and 2020-03-01T00:00Z-03:00Z.  This slight elevation of geomagnetic activity was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around 2020-02-28.  The solar wind speed reached values of around 580 km/s on 2020-02-29.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2020-03-04T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2020-03-10T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  There are no significant active regions present on the solar surface.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the arrival of a small coronal hole high speed stream around 2020-03-06, and a possible glancing blow on 2020-03-07 from the S-type CME (<500 km/s) that started at 2020-03-02T20:09Z as seen from STEREO A coronagraph.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score
